newsitem.title: CANADA: UGG shares continue climb on takeover bid.
newsitem.headline: UGG shares continue climb on takeover bid.

text.p: United Grain Growers Ltd shares continued to set record highs on Friday morning on the Toronto Stock Exchange after Thursday's hostile C$172 million takover bid by two rival grain handlers.
UGG shares rose C$0.05 to C$14.30 in light volume of 7,378 shares.

Alberta Wheat Pool and Manitoba Pool Elevators on Thursday made a C$13.75 a share bid for all remaining outstanding common voting shares in UGG citing the threat of a U.S. multinational takeover of UGG.
UGG share values soared Thursday C$1.75 each to close at 14.25, prompting UGG chief executive earlier Friday to call the pools' bid inadequate.
"I think it shows that agricultural assets are really undervalued in Canada," one equities analyst said.
The stock's rise may cast a "halo effect" on other issues, promoting increased interest, the analyst said.
Commodity analysts dismissed AWP and MPE's claim their bid was to stave off a UGG takeover by a U.S.-based multinational.
Those analysts said they suspected AWP and MPE made their bid for UGG to prevent rival grain handler Saskatchewan Wheat Pool from expanding any further in their provinces.
SWP has recently built and acquired elevators in Manitoba and Alberta.
SWP said it was "an interested observer" of the bid and declined all other comment.
U.S. multinational ConAgra Inc has been the most frequently cited potential suitor for a UGG takeover in the past year. Officials at ConAgra declined comment.
Trade rumours now have ConAgra and UGG in merger talks with ConAgra paying C$15 a share to acquire UGG.
UGG's chief executive was not immediately available for comment.
